column6:

column4: >1. Participate and help your favorite lab or institution win a $5,000 grant (for their lab) or a $20,000 grant (for their institution). Be sure to mention the name of your favorite lab or institution after you contribute. Here's how:
column6:
>

After you make your contribution here on Indiegogo, you'll receive an email within 24 hours from Scientist Solutions. Open that email and click on the name of your favorite Lab or Institution to help them win these grants. If we meet our funding goal, then whoever gets the most name mentions wins!

(The winners will be determined by the number of contributions, not the amount of money donated.  Even $1 donations can help you win! In the event of a tie, the winner will be determined by the total amount donated in the name of your favorite Lab or Institution.)

column7: >3. Cool Perks:

column5:
>4. How Scientist Solutions Helps Scientists
Find Cures for Disease Faster:
column9:
>Scientist Solutions is a collaborative website. It's like Wikipedia in the amount of scientific information it houses, and it's like Facebook in how Scientists can interact and collaborate on our Forums.
We help accelerate the pace of scientific discovery by enabling scientists around the world to collaborate online in real time, all for free.  This helps scientists find cures for diseases faster and save millions of lives.
column10: >(CLICK HERE to Watch a video  about how scientific collaboration helped contain SARS before it became a worldwide epidemic

column3:
>We are one of the largest Life Science collaboration websites in the world.

Over the past 3 years we have been studied by a National Science Foundation grant recipient as one of the two best sites for scientists on the Internet. On our own we have bootstrapped and been able to grow the company to the point of reaching 1 million scientists a year. And we have advanced science thousands of times. But it’s not enough.

With an estimated 12-15 million life science researchers worldwide we are just scratching the surface.
With your help, we will connect 100% of the world's Life Scientists and cause an explosion of scientific discovery that can literally change our planet.

column4: >5. Where in the World Are Our Scientists?
column6:
>Scientists from 163 countries collaborate on our website
to find cures for disease faster

column5: >6. Why the World Needs Scientist Solutions:
column7:
>

Life science researchers spend hours each week looking for products, protocols (recipes for experiments) and information. When a scientist/researcher gets “stuck “or has a challenge with their experiment, they can post a question on one of our moderated forums and often within hours they will have solutions posted from other scientists around the world. Because our forums are moderated by scientists, the answers to posted questions aren’t just crazy ideas posted by anyone, they are well-thought out and reality-based scientifi
column8:
>c answers that help move a scientist’s research forward.

Each question answered can save a scientist one month, two months, or even six months in their experiment. Take 1 million scientists and add up the time savings and you can begin to see how we are helping to accelerate the pace of scientific discovery and finding cures for disease.

NOW WE WANT TO REACH ALL 15 MILLION LIFE SCIENTISTS. BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP.
column10:
>

MORE COLLABORATION = FASTER CURES
These are all the areas of life science we help solve problems in.

column8:
>8. Use of Funds

How we will spend the money we raise:
column9:
>1. Website Development: We desperately need to overhaul the code of our website. After we re-code our website to make it stable and strong, we'll be poised to connect all 15 Million Life Scientists of the world.

 $4500/month for 24 months = $108,000
column10:
>2. Staffing:

We're so grateful to all our moderators who have generously donated their time to forward scientific collaboration on our site. It's about time they got paid what they're worth!
column11:
>We'll use Indiegogo funds to pay our awesome staff:

Stipends for Moderators: $200/month (24 months) for 26 moderators = $124,800

2 Support Staff (12 months) = 2 Support Staff at $3200/month x 12 months = $38,400

Our goal is $270,000. But we'll let you in on a little secret: our real goal is to raise $1 Million through this Indiegogo campaign (April 15 - June 14, 2013)!

If we raise way more than our Indiegogo goal, we have even more plans.

We will dedicate the proceeds to populating our GATCAT.com Site (patent pending) with product reviews and work towards the goal of aggregating the world’s millions of life science products from over 600 suppliers (all our customers) in one convenient place so scientists won’t have to search and research so many sites when they are designing their experiments.

Additionally we would hire additional support staff for our Events Division of ScientistSolutionsEvents.com where we connect our 600 supplier clients to scientists on site at their institutions so the two may have regular contact on the latest and most innovative products.

Please help us blow our goal out of the water so we can do everything we're dreaming of to help the Life Scientists of the World!

column8:
>Scientist Solutions is a majority woman owned company dedicated to life science advocacy worldwide.

Scientist Solutions Inc. was started in 2004 for the purpose of promoting the worldwide advancement of science and biotechnology. To achieve this goal we have developed an internet discussion site or ""Board"" to provide scientists a resource for the exchange of ideas and information.

column3:
>A Note from Marcia (Founder of Scientist Solutions)

The inspiration for Scientist Solutions came from two places: 
I saw the power of E-Bay many years ago to connect people:  What one person sees as trash is treasure to someone else.   While working with Southern BioTech, I saw scientists struggling every day to find antibodies.  Back then producing a monoclonal antibody was a 9 month process and the result wasn't guaranteed.  I saw my boss, Charles Lichtman, the CEO connecting scientists from one lab to another to share antibodies.  With the emergence of the Internet I felt there needed to be a hub for scientists to connect and share information, problem solve and even collaborate.
column5: >For instance, if one scientist in China shares an antibody from his or her freezer with a scientist in California, that can potentially save several months in an experiment.

column3:
>If we improve efficiencies throughout all aspects of research, we can accelerate life science, finding cures years earlier.

Help us connect every scientist in the world and together we can change the world. Thank you!

column1:
Alfred Lagaya - Co-Founder
Scientist Solutions Events
column2: >I was a scientist at AxyS Pharmaceuticals in La Jolla, CA where our research revolved around high-throughput, genetic disease study programs such as Diabetes, Asthma, Schizophrenia, and Osteoporosis, prior to joining a sales team selling disposables for HTS and other science applications. Marcia and I were disturbed seeing reps walking into labs and invading scientists’ privacy. As reps ourselves, we were extremely uncomfortable walking into scientists personal bench spaces. We realized scientists needed access to technology and products but wanted to completely change the process of selling into labs. We started putting on vendor shows in 1998 with about two dozen vendor friends to get the lab doors closed, while improving the efficiency of the flow of information to scientists. About five years later we formerly incorporated BioTech Solutions. Today the company is called Scientist Solutions Events. We hope you have enjoyed less interruption of your experiments. Please let us know if you would like us to host an event at your Institution.

column2: >David Klein joined Scientist Solutions after a 25 year career in the Technology Sector of the Silicon Valley.After working for or with companies like HP, Siebel Systems, Microsoft, Intel and Legend (now Lenovo), he was intrigued by what we are doing here at Scientist Solutions.

column1:
Fraser Moss - President
Scientist Solutions, Inc.

I am Fraser Moss, President of ScientistSolutions.com and also known as TheFFM on the site. I have a Ph. D. in Pharmacology from University College London and postdoc experience at the California Institute of Technology and Case Western Reserve University as well as spending some time in industry. My research has focused predominantly on neuronal ion channel and neurotransmitter transporter biophysics. I have extensive training in electrophysiology, fluorescence imaging, molecular biology and protein biochemistry and have employed these techniques to investigate the oligomerization, stoichiometry, trafficking and pharmacology of these elegant multimeric proteins in both normal and disease states. Before I became a moderator and then President of the site, I found ScientistSolutions.com in 2005 while looking for information on the web to troubleshoot a problem with my research. I've been logged on ever since. 

I quickly recognized the site’s power to allow quick interaction with peers from all over the world to help obtain the information I needed. I have gained a great deal of satisfaction sharing my own knowledge and experience on the site. I hope to continue to help my fellow scientists through ScientistSolutions.com for many more years and see the site become the first port of call for life-scientists worldwide when they turn on their web browsers.

column1:
Ginny Pearce
Moderator of Mitochondria Research

My overall research centers on human gender specific stem cell renewal with the objective of advancing the understanding and treatment of disease and injury. Adult stem cells are capable of renewing themselves, and/or generating multiple cell types during normal growth and repair. However, these capabilities can also play a role in diseased states that are associated with inflammatory response/stress and cancer. To harness and take advantage of renewal capabilities, my research focuses on two areas (1) optimization and characterization of adult stem cell cultures for renewal and selection of cell subtypes, and (2) identification and subcellular localization of certain mitochondrial associated proteins that mediate stem cell renewal/survival. The types of adult stem cells used in these studies include human neural stem cells derived from fetal tissue and mammary epithelial stem cells. Proteins of interest studied include stem cell markers for identification of cell types, and mitochondrial associated proteins survivin, p53, cytochrome c, TOM20, nuclear receptors, and hTERT for renewal. My research efforts are aimed at determining subtypes and their associated proteins as potential targets for pharmacological mediation of stem cell renewal. I am fortunate to collaborate with both institutional and industry sources to develop and culture gender specific stems cell lines.

Staffing: We're so grateful to all our moderators who have generously donated their time to forward scientific collaboration on our site. It's about time they got paid what they're worth!We'll use Indiegogo funds to pay our awesome staff:Stipends for Moderators: $200/month (24 months) for 26 moderators = $124,8002 Support Staff (12 months) = 2 Support Staff at $3200/month x 12 months = $38,400 Our goal is $270,000. But we'll let you in on a little secret: our real goal is to raise $1 Million through this Indiegogo campaign (April 15 - June 14, 2013)! If we raise way more than our Indiegogo goal, we have even more plans. We will dedicate the proceeds to populating our GATCAT.com Site (patent pending) with product reviews and work towards the goal of aggregating the world’s millions of life science products from over 600 suppliers (all our customers) in one convenient place so scientists won’t have to search and research so many sites when they are designing their experiments. Additionally we would hire additional support staff for our Events Division of ScientistSolutionsEvents.com where we connect our 600 supplier clients to scientists on site at their institutions so the two may have regular contact on the latest and most innovative products.  Please help us blow our goal out of the water so we can do everything we're dreaming of to help the Life Scientists of the World!

9. About UsScientist Solutions is a majority woman owned company dedicated to life science advocacy worldwide.Scientist Solutions Inc. was started in 2004 for the purpose of promoting the worldwide advancement of science and biotechnology. To achieve this goal we have developed an internet discussion site or ""Board"" to provide scientists a resource for the exchange of ideas and information.

A Note from Marcia (Founder of Scientist Solutions)The inspiration for Scientist Solutions came from two places:   I saw the power of E-Bay many years ago to connect people:  What one person sees as trash is treasure to someone else.   While working with Southern BioTech, I saw scientists struggling every day to find antibodies.  Back then producing a monoclonal antibody was a 9 month process and the result wasn't guaranteed.  I saw my boss, Charles Lichtman, the CEO connecting scientists from one lab to another to share antibodies.  With the emergence of the Internet I felt there needed to be a hub for scientists to connect and share information, problem solve and even collaborate. For instance, if one scientist in China shares an antibody from his or her freezer with a scientist in California, that can potentially save several months in an experiment.

If we improve efficiencies throughout all aspects of research, we can accelerate life science, finding cures years earlier. Help us connect every scientist in the world and together we can change the world. Thank you!
Welcome from Scientist Solutions' Team Leaders

Alfred Lagaya - Co-Founder Scientist Solutions EventsI was a scientist at AxyS Pharmaceuticals in La Jolla, CA where our research revolved around high-throughput, genetic disease study programs such as Diabetes, Asthma, Schizophrenia, and Osteoporosis, prior to joining a sales team selling disposables for HTS and other science applications. Marcia and I were disturbed seeing reps walking into labs and invading scientists’ privacy. As reps ourselves, we were extremely uncomfortable walking into scientists personal bench spaces. We realized scientists needed access to technology and products but wanted to completely change the process of selling into labs. We started putting on vendor shows in 1998 with about two dozen vendor friends to get the lab doors closed, while improving the efficiency of the flow of information to scientists. About five years later we formerly incorporated BioTech Solutions. Today the company is called Scientist Solutions Events. We hope you have enjoyed less interruption of your experiments. Please let us know if you would like us to host an event at your Institution.
David Klein - Chief Executive Officer, Scientist Solutions, Inc., Scientist Solutions Events & GATCAT

David Klein joined Scientist Solutions after a 25 year career in the Technology Sector of the Silicon Valley.After working for or with companies like HP, Siebel Systems, Microsoft, Intel and Legend (now Lenovo), he was intrigued by what we are doing here at Scientist Solutions.

“Having a brother with ALS and knowing there is very little funding for this terrible disease makes me passionate to help scientists in their quest for discovery and cures.  I hope to use my experience in technology, both with prominent companies and successful growth of my own start up to propel the Scientist Solutions organization and family to make a difference in life science""
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Fraser Moss - President Scientist Solutions, Inc. I am Fraser Moss, President of ScientistSolutions.com and also known as TheFFM on the site. I have a Ph. D. in Pharmacology from University College London and postdoc experience at the California Institute of Technology and Case Western Reserve University as well as spending some time in industry. My research has focused predominantly on neuronal ion channel and neurotransmitter transporter biophysics. I have extensive training in electrophysiology, fluorescence imaging, molecular biology and protein biochemistry and have employed these techniques to investigate the oligomerization, stoichiometry, trafficking and pharmacology of these elegant multimeric proteins in both normal and disease states. Before I became a moderator and then President of the site, I found ScientistSolutions.com in 2005 while looking for information on the web to troubleshoot a problem with my research. I've been logged on ever since.   I quickly recognized the site’s power to allow quick interaction with peers from all over the world to help obtain the information I needed. I have gained a great deal of satisfaction sharing my own knowledge and experience on the site. I hope to continue to help my fellow scientists through ScientistSolutions.com for many more years and see the site become the first port of call for life-scientists worldwide when they turn on their web browsers.
Meet our fantastic team of scientist moderators

Scientist Solutions was created FOR scientists and is run BY scientists. Our moderators are a dedicated bunch of  life scientists who read and answer posts,  look up information for you and help keep our board organized and orderly.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Guy Sovak - Canadian Memorial Chiropractic College Chief Scientist and Moderator of Anatomy & Physiology, Biomaterials, Microscopy & Imaging andCytology, Histology & IHC.I graduated with a degree in Education of Biological Sciences, and proceeded to do a MSc. at the Faculty of Medicine in the Technion, Haifa Israel. Nowadays I am researching fascia and intermuscular connective tissue in the psoas major muscle and its implication on non-uniform psoas deformation under tensile load using histology, immunohistology and biochemistry methods. One of my main interests lies in finding whether there are differences in protein levels within different cross-sectional planes in and the effects on treatment load transfer through soft tissue during therapy.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Ivan Delgado - President and CEO of Mouse Genotype Moderator of DNA (PCR, Real-Time PCR) After 10 years in academic research I moved to industry, where I worked at DNA sequencing companies, genetic testing companies, and biopharmaceutical testing companies, before I started my own genetic testing company. I am currently President and CEO of Mouse Genotype, a company dedicated to providing high quality and affordable mouse genotyping services. I was very lucky early on in my career when I received excellent training form post-docs and professors at various academic institutions. Scientist Solutions gives me the opportunity to give back. At the same time it is also a great venue to keep up to date with what scientists are doing in the laboratory.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me
Sambuddho Mukherjee - Duke University Moderator of Antibody Based Technologies and Cell Culture & Tissue Culture

I have been an active member at SSI for well over three years now, having got there through the simple accident of a Google search. The information I got then saved me weeks of trial experiments. It’s a great feeling when I'm able to pay it back and get heartfelt thanks from another researcher.  That's what embodies the spirit that drives this site
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Ed Dunphy - University of Wisconsin Moderator of The Lighter Side of ScienceI’m Edward Dunphy, a research scientist and comic strip writer in Madison, WI.  I grew up in New York, graduated from the University of Chicago and have worked primarily in academic labs in Chicago and Madison since 1985.  I recently made a move into the private sector and I have to say I’m pretty happy with the change thus far. Marcia asked me to join the Scientist Solutions team two years ago after seeing my Lab Bratz science humor webcomic.   As the Moderator for “The Lighter Side of Science” forums, I’ve enjoyed scouring the internet for interesting science quotes, scientist birthdays, weird science facts and science jokes.  I also regularly post the archives of my Lab Bratz webcomic on the forum.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me
Merlin Bicking - President of Analytical Chemistry Consulting and Training Associates, Inc. Moderator of Analytical Chemistry Expert in Chromatography
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me
Jason King- Edinburgh University College of Medicine & Veterinary Medicine

Moderator of VirologyI have been a postdoc at Edinburgh University's College of Medicine & Veterinary Medicine since 2001. My work here has involved using cloning and producing recombinant AAV, Adenovirus and lentiviruses to overexpress or knockdown gene expression to better understand mechanisms involved in inflammation and cancer and very recently,  human ES cell work. I stumbled upon Scientist Solutions just as I was beginning a new project and was happy to find such a friendly community that was always keen to point fellow scientists in the right direction. I found that this matched my (Scouting) scientist values and so now I'm ""doing a good turn every day"" - well almost.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Marcus Muench - Blood Systems Research Institute.   Moderator of Stem Cell TechnologyThe research focus of my laboratory is on development stem cell biology, particularly of the hematopoietic and hepatic systems.  A driving force behind my basic research efforts is a desire for the research to be clinically applicable, particularly in the field of fetal medicine. I believe that an active online community of scientists helping each other is a mutually beneficial arrangement that will foster research progress.  I have found Scientist Solutions to be a new way to meet colleagues that share similar research interests.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me
Peter Barlow- Centers for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC)

Moderator of ImmunologyI joined Scientist Solutions after being introduced to it by the Virology moderator, Jason King, while I was a postdoc in the Centre for Inflammation Research at the University of Edinburgh.  I am now a Fellow in the Influenza Division at the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention in Atlanta, Georgia.  My primary interests lie in modulating the immune response to bacterial and viral infection.  I'm very happy to be a part of what is a fantastic and valuable resource for every person in the scientific community.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Sami Tuomivaara - Moderator of Protein Chemistry & BioinformaticsI’m currently pursuing a PhD degree in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology. My dissertation work focuses on the structure and function of plant cell wall, a topic which I find intellectually extremely challenging. Besides cell wall research, I’m interested in a wide range of topics in biosciences and I hope this multidisciplinary interest and the depth of my training will help me to be an independent researcher in the future. In the summer of 2009, a colleague introduced me to SSI and I started contributing soon after that. After less than one year stint as a regular contributor to the SSI forums, I was asked to join the moderators’ team, which I gladly accepted. I hope this way I can give back the scientific community some of the knowledge I have received over the years.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me
Gaganjot Singh - University of Delhi  Moderator of Cancer, Diagnostics & Proteomics

I’m Gaganjot Singh also known as Argerine on the ScientistSolutions.com. I have my Ph.D. in Biochemistry with specialization in cancer proteomics from University of Delhi, India. My research work is based on the screening of protein based serological markers for diagnosis of lung, breast and ovarian carcinomas. I am currently teaching Cell and Molecular Biology to the under graduate students at University of Delhi. I joined SSI in April, 2009 and as a moderator in 2011. The fabulous part of Scientist Solutions lies in the fact that a large number of professionals from all over the world, provide expert help based upon their own research experience. Together in SSI, we are determined to help and discuss the problems faced by fellow scientists and researchers to explore the numerous fantastic possibilities of science.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me
Chin Fen Teo   Moderator of Protein Chemistry & Glycobiology

I am currently pursuing my PhD degree in Biochemistry, focusing on the impact of glycosylation on cell signaling. I stumbled across Scientist Solutions one summer evening of 2009 while searching for a “second opinion” regarding one of the experiments I was working on. Having read some of the threads on the forum, I realized that I could also contribute and help others to overcome their problems similar to mine, which I spent days or weeks or even months figuring out by myself. Hence I started actively posting my tips and thoughts. In the spring of 2010, I gratefully accepted an invitation to join the team of Scientist Solutions' moderators. I hope that as a moderator, I can continue helping others in the true spirit of science.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Qiang Wang - Michigan State University Moderator of Protein Dection I had always admired that Scientist Solutions could do so much for the scientific community, so I became a member in 2006. In November of last year I was selected to be moderator of the Protein Detection and Plant Biology forum. I am proud to be on the Scientist Solutions team working hard to contribute more to society.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Ginny PearceModerator of Mitochondria ResearchMy overall research centers on human gender specific stem cell renewal with the objective of advancing the understanding and treatment of disease and injury. Adult stem cells are capable of renewing themselves, and/or generating multiple cell types during normal growth and repair. However, these capabilities can also play a role in diseased states that are associated with inflammatory response/stress and cancer. To harness and take advantage of renewal capabilities, my research focuses on two areas (1) optimization and characterization of adult stem cell cultures for renewal and selection of cell subtypes, and (2) identification and subcellular localization of certain mitochondrial associated proteins that mediate stem cell renewal/survival. The types of adult stem cells used in these studies include human neural stem cells derived from fetal tissue and mammary epithelial stem cells. Proteins of interest studied include stem cell markers for identification of cell types, and mitochondrial associated proteins survivin, p53, cytochrome c, TOM20, nuclear receptors, and hTERT for renewal. My research efforts are aimed at determining subtypes and their associated proteins as potential targets for pharmacological mediation of stem cell renewal. I am fortunate to collaborate with both institutional and industry sources to develop and culture gender specific stems cell lines.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Varsha Singh - Duke University Moderator of Microbiology, Proteomics and Model OrganismsI am Varsha Singh. I am currently a postdoctoral fellow in a Microbial Pathogenesis Lab at Duke University Med center. I am so excited about microbes that I have them pervade my work, personal life and hobbies. I have even done an oil painting of a macrophage infected with Pneumophila (PDF available on request). So, when I got an opportunity to be part of Scientistsolutions as a moderator for ‘Microbiology, I leapt at it. It has been tons of fun and a learning experience. It is easier and fun to share than to go alone. Since then I am also become a moderator for “Proteomics”.  A recently added “Model Organisms’ forum, is my favorite as it includes C. elegans.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Rusty Bishop   Moderator of Protein ChemistryI earned my PhD in Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics from the University of Alabama-Birmingham. The exciting part of Scientist Solutions is helping scientists get their experiments done faster. I love it when someone figures out a tough experiment that has taken months of their valuable time. That’s what every part of the company is really about - pushing back the frontiers through communication.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Omai Garner - UCLA Moderator of General, Genetics and Bioethics.My name is Omai Garner, and I am a postdoctoral researcher at UCLA in the department of pathology. I work in the lab of Dr. Linda Baum and study the role of glycosylation in innate immunity and viral pathology. I was always taught that science, at its best, is a collaborative process. It’s collaboration, and not competition, which produces the most significant advances in biomedical research.  This website provides a rare opportunity for scientists to interact with others worldwide through a well organized and useful discussion forum.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Chris Fisher - Private Industry Moderator of Biochemistry, Biophysics, Organic Chemistry and Animal & Veterinary TechnologyI am currently a Microbiologist at STERIS Corporation involved in the research and development of disinfectants and sterilants for the medical industry, including business acquisitions and licensing opportunities.  I received my Ph.D. in Microbiology from the University of Illinois, Champaign-Urbana. The great aspect of working for SSI is that everyone is encouraged to provide their ideas for developing the site.   Scientist Solutions is really being developed by scientists, for scientists.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Ryan Morin - British Columbia Genome Sciences Centre Moderator of GenomicsMy name is Ryan Morin and I am currently pursuing a doctorate degree in bioinformatics at the Genome Sciences Centre in Vancouver, Canada.  I have been the moderator for the Genomics forum at Scientist Solutions for the past 3 years.  I started moderating for the board after being a user/contributor for several months. Scientist Solutions has been a great way to find answers to problems I’ve encountered in my research.  It has also been useful in meeting people with common research interests.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Ben Good - University of British Columbia Moderator of BioinformaticsI'm finishing up my PhD. in bioinformatics at the University of British Columbia.  My research has focused around  defining new ways to create, measure, and apply the components of the  semantic Web for the life sciences.  I'm particularly interested in  social tagging (e.g. Connotea, Del.icio.us) and other approaches to  community-driven creation of metadata.   I've been involved with SSI since 2006.  Looking forward, I hope, to continue to contribute both as a technical advisor on Web-related aspects of information science and as a participant in the forums.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Shareef Nahas - Harvard University Moderator of DNA (PCR, Real Time PCR) I am a post doctoral fellow in the department of Pathology and laboratory medicine at UCLA working on identifiying defective gene products in rare genetic orphan diseases. Since joining Scientist Solutions, I have not only been able to help and meet wonderful people through the numerous scientific categories and like research interests, but I have learned ... and continue to learn ... new and exciting techniques and ideas from others on the site.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Moderator of Pharmacology & Drug DiscoveryI am a diversely trained scientist with a background in genetics, C. elegans biology, bioinformatics and nanotechnology. I am currently at the Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology department at UCSB. I am very interested in molecular diagnostics, drug discovery and development and have been moderating these forums at SSI since 2006. I look forward to the stimulating discussions here and helping our community to the best extent possible.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Anjuli Timmer - UC-San Diego Moderator of MicrobiologyMy name is Anjuli Timmer and I co-moderate the Microbiology forum of Scientist Solutions. I did my undergraduate in Biology at the University of New Hampshire and after working as an Associate Scientist at AME for 2 years, joined the Molecular Pathology PhD program at the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine. My favorite part about Scientist Solutions is how many different people from different countries are involved – not only as members, but also participating in the company.   It has really brought scientists from all over the world together to help each other.
Go to My Bench Space / Contact me

Saswati Hazra - UCLA Moderator of Pharmacology & Drug DiscoveryI am a Research Faculty at the division of Pulmonary and Critical Care, Department of Medicine, UCLA and my research work involves the area including Lung Cancer treatment and chemoprevention. I used to go to the SSI site to get help and then one day I saw a flyer hanging in the corridor looking for moderators. I contacted Marcia, who gladly accepted my request to volunteer.   I’ve learned a lot here. If I did not know the answer to a question, I was encouraged to go to pubmed to find the answer.   That way I also learned something new!

My name is Dr. Randy Gastwirt. I am a post-doctoral fellow in the Departments of Orthopedics at UC San Diego and the Veterans Hospital.  I am originally from Brooklyn, NY but have called myself a Californian since high School. I got my BA in Biology from Pomona College and my PhD in Biomedical Sciences from UC San Diego School of Medicine. I joined the Scientist Solutions team almost a year ago because I believed that our site could have a major impact on the world of research science. In the future I envision a site that provides scientists with everything they need to do their research.  My current role is to increase web traffic though link exchanges and by spreading SS content, news and information around the web.

I work at the National Brain Research Centre, a pioneer institute in India for research in Neuroscience.  I have 10 years experience in microbiology and histolgy, cytology and IHC.  I did my PG in lifescience and PG diploma in Biomedical Lab technology. I joined SSI as member in 2008 after seeing the SSI flyers in an adjacent lab.  Ever since, this has been my favorite place to visit on the web and I love helping our fellow members with their queries.  This is a fantastic science forum with a knowledge bank full of the expertise of numerous eminent scientists from around the world.
Amarnath Annamalai Director - India & Customer Services Manager

I am a Ph.D. Research Student in the Department of Animal Science, Bharathidasan University, Tamil Nadu, India. One day, while doing research on the web, I discovered Scientist Solutions and began a chat with Marcia. During our conversation, she asked me to promote the site in India and continuously inspired me to succeed. I am now Director of India for SSI and coordinating special projects for both SSI and SSE. In the past four years of my experience in SSI, I enjoyed meeting new people from various countries. Without their contribution we couldn't have grown. Thanks all! I welcome all indian scientists to our board and we can make a new history in life sciences once we assembled under one roof.

I promote SSI to my distribution company customers and my friends by introducing them to the fantastic possibilities and advantages of the SSI website. Awareness of SSI and SSE in Europe is growing, but it’s not where it could be. Let’s conquer this market by sharing the opportunities! TOGETHER WE CAN!

I am a Senior Research Scientist at Bayer with previous experience as a research Scientist at Merck, The Burnham Institute (under John Reed), and Elan Pharmaceuticals.   I founded a reference lab in China which over the past years has grown to annual revenue of $10 million.

I was senior software engineer working for Dept. of Defense contractor DefenseWeb Technologies. After joining Scientist Solutions, we have made a lot of improvements to the website. Almost every month we release new features that make the system better and better. We have received a lot of feedback from our members saying that we are doing a great job and that they see our website is getting better and better... I believe the company is set up to promote success. I love Scientist Solutions and the culture around here. People are motivated and things are getting done very fast.

Kızım İpek 7 yaşında, bundan 5 yıl önce yani İpek 2 yaşında iken kulağının duymadığı şüphesiyle doktora götürdüm. Kulağında hiç bir sorun olmadığını ama otizm başlangıcı olabileceğini söylediler, yaklaşık bir ay sonra tam teşhis koydular. O yaşlarda İpek ismine tepki vermiyor söylenen her şeye bağırarak, çığlık atarak cevap vermeye çalışıyordu.

Bizim için terapinin uygun olduğunu otizmin ilaçla tedavisi olmadığını söylediler ve İpek therapilere başladı (Ot,Speech,ABA) tabiki bu terapilerin çok faydasını görüyoruz ve hala devam ediyoruz. Ama ben uzun süreli araştırmalarımdan ve diğer ailelerle konuşmalarım neticesindebiomedical treatment'in otizmi geri çevirdiği kanısına vardım ve hatta bu tedavi yöntemine başladım, ilk olarak gfçf dieti yaptım tam 1 hafta sonra kızımın bana tek kelimeli cümle kurduğunu, geceleri çığlık atarak uyanmalarının bittiğini ve benimle göz kontağı yaptığını gördüm.

Bunun terapilerden mi yoksa diyetten mi olduğunu anlamak için tam 2 hafta diyete ara verdim. Terapiler devam ediyordu fakat İpek çığlıklarına geri döndü, anladım ki diyet İpek'de muazzam değişilikler yaptı, bunun yanısıra vitaminler ve methyl b12 aşısı.

İpek tek kelimeden 3 kelimeye başladı şimdi puzzleın bir parçası kaldı, otizm rahatsızlığı çok masraflı ve meşakatli bir rahatsızlık. Puzzleın en büyük parçası ""hypebaricoxygen chamber"" bu tedavinin son günlerde otizmle ilgili iyi neticeler verdiği belilenmiştir. Ama benim bu tedaviyi karşılayacak maddi gücüm olmadığından yaptıramıyorum hayatta en çok istediğim şey bir gün kızımın bana annecim seni çok seviyorum demesi.

column2: >Bemelsa needs a new kitchen! We serve two hot meals every day to over 200 people, and it really takes its toll on our facilities. After being an essential part of our community as such for 30 years, we have a lot of work to do!

column1: Bemelsa is short for Beata Melchorita Saravia, a woman who dedicated her life to feeding the people and bettering the community of Grocio Prado, and is now a sort of patron saint of the pueblo. We are a non-profit comedor, or dining hall, in Grocio Prado, Peru.

Over 200 children, disabled adults, and the elderly come to enjoy a hot meal two times a day. We’ve been in operation for over 30 years, and in the last 5 have added programs involving educational and social support.

Everyone who comes to eat at the Comedor really needs the food we offer them - financially, they wouldn't be able to provide it for themselves. Furthermore, many of the kids come from a background of broken families, domestic abuse, and a family history of deliquency. The Comedor is a safe space whose programs give the youth of Grocio Prado a fighting chance to break out of the cycle of poverty into which they were born. As a local grassroots NGO, we rely almost completely on charitable donors, and we sincerely hope that you’ll join our family as one of them!

Serving two hot meals to over 200 people every day takes its toll on our facilities. That's 400 meals a day, which is 2000 meals a week and a staggering 104,000 meals a year! Multiply that by 30 and it's not so hard to see why we're in such dire need of renovation.

In order to keep the Comedor alive and in ship-shape, we need to do a complete overhaul on the kitchen. This includes a new industrial refrigerator and stove-top, all new dishes and serving utencils, cutlery and crockery. In total, our expenses for these purchases will run to 10,100 nuevos soles, or around $3950 USD. The extra $350 USD in our goal is to account for travel to and  Lima (the capital) and back to make the purchases, cleaning supplies to help with the overhaul and the percentage that Indiegogo will take.
The following list is a breakdown of EXACTLY what we need:

Basic nutrition is an essential human right. Every donation, no matter the size, ensures  that over 200 youth and disabled and/or elderly adults are able to eat at least two meals daily! With your help, Bemelsa's chicos and chicas will continue having access to a solid source of daily nutrition.
In return, we'll send you the smiles and thanks of our bright and budding Peruvian chiquitos and jóvencitos!
But keeping the Comedor open today means that the impoverished in the community of Grocio Prado will have hot meals and educational and social support for the next 30 years and more!
Like the saying goes, ""it takes a village to raise a child"", and we're talking about 200 kids here! So please spread the word and keep our kids fed and happy. :)
Share our Campaign or Bemelsa's website with friends and family via the Indiegogo share tools, Facebook, Twitter, email, or word-of-mouth. Every bit helps!
• If you're not sure you want to donate through Indiegogo, consider donating to us directly through Just Give at https://npo.justgive.org/nonprofits/donate.jsp?ein=27-3961623
• If you feel insecure about donating over the Web, we also gladly accept donations via cheque or money order at:

Bemelsa Alaska, Inc
1124 I Street
Anchorage, Alaska 99501
EIN Number for IRS Charitable Tax Deductions: 27-27-3961623

Kellen Jackson is an 18-year-old from Edmonton, Canada who teaches English and Choral classes to the kids, and helps with tutoring in English, Math, and Writing. She is starting her BFA in Film at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver this September.

Josue Ruiz is an 18-year-old from San Salvador, El Salvador who teaches English and Computer classes, as well as helping with one-on-one tutorials. He is an experienced international volunteer, and is starting his BCom in North Carolina this September.

Yolanda Elias is a 21-year-old from Ottawa, Canada who is teaching a Politics course to our older youth that is also open to the general youth of Grocio Prado. She aims to inform the kids about the political process and encourage them to get involved in their local government. She is entering her fourth year at the University of Ottawa.

Bemelsa needs a new kitchen! We serve two hot meals every day to over 200 people, and it really takes its toll on our facilities. After being an essential part of our community as such for 30 years, we have a lot of work to do!

Bemelsa is short for Beata Melchorita Saravia, a woman who dedicated her life to feeding the people and bettering the community of Grocio Prado, and is now a sort of patron saint of the pueblo. We are a non-profit comedor, or dining hall, in Grocio Prado, Peru.

Over 200 children, disabled adults, and the elderly come to enjoy a hot meal two times a day. We’ve been in operation for over 30 years, and in the last 5 have added programs involving educational and social support.

Everyone who comes to eat at the Comedor really needs the food we offer them - financially, they wouldn't be able to provide it for themselves. Furthermore, many of the kids come from a background of broken families, domestic abuse, and a family history of deliquency. The Comedor is a safe space whose programs give the youth of Grocio Prado a fighting chance to break out of the cycle of poverty into which they were born. As a local grassroots NGO, we rely almost completely on charitable donors, and we sincerely hope that you’ll join our family as one of them!

Serving two hot meals to over 200 people every day takes its toll on our facilities. That's 400 meals a day, which is 2000 meals a week and a staggering 104,000 meals a year! Multiply that by 30 and it's not so hard to see why we're in such dire need of renovation.

In order to keep the Comedor alive and in ship-shape, we need to do a complete overhaul on the kitchen. This includes a new industrial refrigerator and stove-top, all new dishes and serving utencils, cutlery and crockery. In total, our expenses for these purchases will run to 10,100 nuevos soles, or around $3950 USD. The extra $350 USD in our goal is to account for travel to and  Lima (the capital) and back to make the purchases, cleaning supplies to help with the overhaul and the percentage that Indiegogo will take.
The following list is a breakdown of EXACTLY what we need:

Basic nutrition is an essential human right. Every donation, no matter the size, ensures  that over 200 youth and disabled and/or elderly adults are able to eat at least two meals daily! With your help, Bemelsa's chicos and chicas will continue having access to a solid source of daily nutrition.
In return, we'll send you the smiles and thanks of our bright and budding Peruvian chiquitos and jóvencitos!
But keeping the Comedor open today means that the impoverished in the community of Grocio Prado will have hot meals and educational and social support for the next 30 years and more!
Like the saying goes, ""it takes a village to raise a child"", and we're talking about 200 kids here! So please spread the word and keep our kids fed and happy. :)
Share our Campaign or Bemelsa's website with friends and family via the Indiegogo share tools, Facebook, Twitter, email, or word-of-mouth. Every bit helps!
If you're not sure you want to donate through Indiegogo, consider donating to us directly through Just Give at https://npo.justgive.org/nonprofits/donate.jsp?ein=27-3961623
If you feel insecure about donating over the Web, we also gladly accept donations via cheque or money order at:
Bemelsa Alaska, Inc 1124 I Street Anchorage, Alaska 99501
EIN Number for IRS Charitable Tax Deductions: 27-27-3961623

Kellen Jackson is an 18-year-old from Edmonton, Canada who teaches English and Choral classes to the kids, and helps with tutoring in English, Math, and Writing. She is starting her BFA in Film at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver this September.

Josue Ruiz is an 18-year-old from San Salvador, El Salvador who teaches English and Computer classes, as well as helping with one-on-one tutorials. He is an experienced international volunteer, and is starting his BCom in North Carolina this September.

Yolanda Elias is a 21-year-old from Ottawa, Canada who is teaching a Politics course to our older youth that is also open to the general youth of Grocio Prado. She aims to inform the kids about the political process and encourage them to get involved in their local government. She is entering her fourth year at the University of Ottawa.",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

When it comes right down to it the most important part of scoring low in golf is being an excellent putter. Since most golfers, professionals included, move their head when they putt, their putting scores will be erratic. The O'Beam is a simple training aid - it provides immediate feedback about head movement, allowing golfers to correct the problem, which reduces putts and lowers their score.

The O'Beam started as a simple way to show my friend and student how much he was moving his head when putting. No matter what I did he still could not believe he was moving his head. I decided I needed to come up with something that will show him immediately how much his head was truly moving. I designed a laser to affix to the bill of a visor or hat that emits an ""O"" on the ball. After his very first stroke he was absolutely shocked
column2: he worked with this device for a few days and before he knew it he was dropping putts and his scores started to drop dramatically.

column1: He was so impressed as well as all of those who watched him practice with it, I was suddenly bombarded with demands for more units. I immediately realized that I needed to get more units, a patent, a logo, several made to meet the demand and I did. Before I knew it I ran into Chip Beck, Champions Tour Player, and he was mesmerized by the O’Beam. He asked for one and wanted to be the endorsing professional. While meeting with Chip Beck, several other Champions Tour Players were trying the O'Beam and were placing orders! Next, I was invited on to the Golf Channel for the Champions Tour Learning Channel to introduce the O'Beam.

column4: />There have been many challenges getting the O'Beam off the ground: patent, trademark, mold, laser design, unit design, packaging, TV interviews, radio interviews, newspaper and magazine interviews.... However, we have been able to overcome every challenge so far except generating enough money to provide this wonderful little device with the exposure it deserves to realize its full potential. There is no doubt that even the best products in the world need the proper exposure to be successful. There have been several marketing companies interested in marketing the O'Beam
column5: however there is a large expense to marketing a product. That is why my biggest challenge is to generate funds to underwrite the marketing expenses. The O'Beam is an excellent product and the beauty is that we already know it is a success! The O'Beam sells itself from the website without adveritising, but even the best products in the world need the proper exposure.

column1: Join the O'Beam team! Improve your game and help see that the O'Beam reaches its full marketing potential. Thank you!
Project by Katie O'Keefe
A GolfConversations.com Interview with Katie O'Keefe, CEO O'BEAM
1. In a nutshell, what's an O'BEAM?

The O'Beam is a laser-guide putting aid that you attach to the bill of your hat. It emits a laser in the shape of an ""O"". When addressing the golf ball in your putting setup, you adjust the laser to have the ""O"" on the center of the golf ball. When you make your putting stroke, the O'Beam will instantly show you how much you are moving your head.
2. How and when did you come up with the idea for OB?

One of my students, Brian Callahan, who is now my business partner, could not keep his head still while putting, which resulted in high golf scores. He was frustrated because he could not recognize when and how much his head was moving. The only thing that I could think of was to attach a laser to his hat. There was no big plan and it was no more than a simple thought at the time.
3. What did your friends/family think when you told them about OB?

I didn't really tell anyone at first because it was just a simple aid to help my student. But when I realized how effective it was and how much it helped Brian, I thought some of my other students might benefit from it. I began to investigate what the next step would be to get O'BEAMs made. I told my family
column2: however, they really didn't understand and I think they figured it would be just a passing interest and fizzle away. When I told my two best friends, though, Paige Phillips and Trish Wodatch, they both responded very nicely. Both were excited and felt that if anyone could make it happen, I could. Of course Brian was wonderful and very excited
column3: he became my business partner in the venture.

column1: 4. You're a golf instructor, not an inventor
column2: what kind of research did you do to learn about laser beams?

column1: I read everything I could, via books and the Internet, about how lasers work.
5. I assume you had to have a person or company with some laser beam ""aptitude"" to help you develop a prototype, yes?

Actually, when I first got started, I had not yet even told Brian about it so I had no money to hire anyone to help me. I did all the research myself and created the first prototype on my own. I hired an engineer only after Brian used my very first prototype. Since I already had all the research completed, I just needed an engineer to put all my information into proper ""engineering terminology"" and do the CAD (computer-aided design) pictures.
6. Did you go through several prototypes before you found the one you wanted? What was that experience like?

No, I really knew from the start exactly what I wanted and the engineer copied my drawings almost to the letter. There was a slight change in shape because the batteries would not fit correctly into the shell of my original design. The clip I wanted was created so that the unit can rotate up and down to accommodate all setups. The only difficult thing for me was communicating with the engineers. Both were wonderful and very helpful. However, I learned in a hurry that you cannot ask an engineer a yes/no question. I wanted the laser to be in the shape of an ""O"" for two reasons: The golf ball is round and an ""O"" would be more visible, and because my last name is O'Keefe. The engineers told me this could not be done, that a laser, if magnified, looks like an asterisk, so there would be no way to make the ""O"" unless we used a screen on the lens that would make an ""O"". However, I knew this would minimize the strength of the laser thus making it difficult to see outside. So the long and the short of it was that I told the engineer to change how the laser sends its energy so that the shape is an ""O"" rather than *.
7. What specifically were you looking for in the final prototype?
Exactly what I wanted: a small, light unit with the laser in the shape of an ""O"" and a clip that rotates up and down.
8. After your prototype was created, did you use it with students? Touring pros? What was their reaction to the OB?

The first tour professional that I talked about it with was Tom Watson. I had contacted Mr. Watson about a friend whom has ALS, hoping that he might reach out to my friend and possibly give him some encouragement, which he did without hesitation. When Tom Watson was speaking with my friend on the phone, my friend told Tom Watson about my idea. Tom Watson then contacted me to ask me about it. I explained the concept and he thought it was a solid idea and wanted to see one when I had a final product. I was encouraged, thinking that if Tom Watson likes this idea, then it might be more successful then I had first anticipated. He put me in touch with Chip Beck. I called Chip
column2: we set up an appointment to meet at a Champions Tour event being held in my town, Palm Coast. We met
column3: he tried it, instantly loved it and was truly excited. He wanted one right then, but it was my original prototype so he had to wait for the first production run.

column1: 9. What convinced you to go from the prototype stage to full production of the OB? What year did this occur?

I don't think it ever occurred to me not to. I knew it worked and I know enough about the golf swing and the golf business that I knew people would want to use it. I started fooling around with the idea in February 2007 and it took about a year of research to apply for a patent and trademark. I was then in a patent-pending stage and we were off and running. After about a year and a half, I was invited to appear on Golf Channel.
10.How many O'BEAMs were produced in the first run?
11.Ok, you've got all these O'BEAMs produced
column2: how did you go about trying to market them?

column1: We set up a Web site, www.obeamputt.com, and had a Google Adwords account using key words that drove traffic to the site. I was also fortunate to have been invited on the Champions Tour Learning Center on Golf Channel. This was a wonderful opportunity for me to introduce the O'Beam on television, and momentum started picking up.

column2: how did you meet Chip and how did you introduce him to the OB?

column1: Tom Watson put me in touch with Chip Beck. I called Chip
column2: we set up an appointment to meet at a Champions Tour event being held in my town, Palm Coast. We met
column3: he tried it, instantly loved it and was truly excited. He wanted one right then, but it was my original prototype so he had to wait for the first production run.

column1: 13. What was Chip's reaction the first time he used OB?

He was amazed by how simple the concept was and how much it helped him. He was excited to see that it provides immediate feedback so that you can correct yourself right away. ""Limited mobility of the head – so important in putting. This product is a must have for all golfers!"" he said. He immediately became my endorsing professional. I am so pleased and feel fortunate to have such a wonderful human being as an endorsing professional.
14. Have any other touring pros used (not necessarily endorsed) OB?

Bruce Fleisher tried it at the Champions Tour event in San Antonio, when we did the Golf Channel spot. He used it on the putting green and immediately loved it. He was so excited, and his energy and Chip's energy carried over to many other players. Bruce used it in his hotel room and the next day he had, I believe 24 putts, low putting round of the day and he had his first top-five finish in several years. Mike Goodes used one, and shortly after I gave him one, he had his first professional victory on the Champions Tour.
15. What's been the reaction of your students to OB?
They love it and want to know why I didn't come up with this idea sooner!
Can it burn your skin or burn grass or carpeting? Yes, it is safe. It is within the guidelines of the government.
17. How many batteries does OB require?
18. OB is designed to help you keep your head still while putting, but can it also be used for the full swing and chipping &
Gary Halberg liked the O'BEAM for his full swing. I very much like the O'BEAM for pitching and chipping as well, and many of my students are using it for that and finding great success.
19. Have you seen improvement in your students who use OB?

Yes, dramatic improvement in their putting scores, drastically lowering their golf score. It is difficult to explain to students how putting is the most important part of the game of golf. The quickest way to lower your golf score is to eliminate putting strokes. Everyone tries to hit farther with their driver rather than just practicing putting and eliminating excessive putts. This is why the O'BEAM has been so successful: When a player's putting improves, his total golf score drops!
20. While we're talking about putting and keeping your head still, is there a particular putting theory to which you subscribe? Straight back-straight-through? Inside-square-inside?

I believe that we are all built differently and stroke the putter differently. However, I believe that no matter how you make your putting stroke, it is imperative for the club face to be square at impact and your head still.
21. Who, in your opinion, are golf's top-3 putters?

Seve Ballasteros had to be the best ever, in my opinion. He rarely hit a green or fairway in regulation but was able to get up-and-down better than anyone in the history of the game, which equates to a lot of one putts. He holds five major titles.
Second would have to be Ben Crenshaw. He always had perfect speed on the ball and it would just die into the hole as if it had eyes.

Jack Nicklaus would be third, in my opinion. Just watch the 1986 Masters and you will see for yourself. As a matter of fact, Ballesteros, Crenshaw and Nicklaus all won at Augusta National, in my opinion the toughest test of putting of any course.
22. Can you recommend any books/DVDs that would work well in conjunction with O'BEAM?
The O'BEAM is so simple to use and provides such instant feedback that it really doesn't need a supplement.
23. Do you have any recommendations as to how long you should practice your putting? (x% full swing, x% putting, x% chipping, etc.)
24. Why is it so difficult to keep your head still while putting?

I think there is a natural instinct to want to see where the ball is going. I tell my students all the time, if you lose a ball on the putting green you should probably be looking for another sport to play. There is no need to look for the ball, but instinctively we all do at some point. Also, many people can't recognize when and how much they are moving, which is what makes the O'BEAM so unique. It gives instant feedback. I can actually read my students' faces, as if a light bulb has gone on when they see how much the O'BEAM has moved. Instantly they begin to train themselves to minimize their head movement.
25. Jimmy Ballard says it's all right to move your head a bit
column2: Jack Nicklaus thinks the head should be perfectly still. How can they both be right? Your thoughts?

column1: I certainly wouldn't question Jack Nicklaus' opinion
column2: he has proven that having virtually no head movement during his swing helped make him one of the greatest players of all time. Jimmy Ballard is correct as well, because I don't think it is humanly possible to keep your head perfectly still. There is apt to be at least a bit of head movement with your swing. I believe it is a happy medium. Minimizing your head movement for your own personal swing is what is important. We all swing the club and putter differently, we are all built differently and we all have limits. Keeping your head still before, during and just after impact is crucial for a successful swing and putting stroke.

column1: 26. SOUND OFF: Katie, use this space to talk about anything you’d like … as long as it’s golf related!
I hope that many people will enjoy improved putting strokes as a result of practicing with O'BEAM.
Humble Beginnings for O'Keefe: Confident O'Keefe Chases Pro Golf Dream in a $1 Car
SURFSIDE BEACH - Katie O'Keefe gave up everything to chase her dream of becoming a professional golfer.
In June of 1991, she left her family, her friends, her home and a solid job as a special education teacher. She traded it all for a $1 car and a dream.
The 29-year-old Rye, N.Y., native packed her big handicap and small financial resources into her newly purchased 1974 Vega and moved from her New York home to the Grand Strand.
For O'Keefe, a former college softball player, it wasn’t a tough decision.
""Not many people get a chance to what they really want to do,"" explained O'Keefe, who lowered a 20-handicap to a five in 15 months. ""I just wanted to play.""
After months of mailing letters and researching for a job where she could pursue a pro golf career, O'Keefe got her chance entirely by accident.

While on vacation in March 1991 with her father, ""Chubby,"" O'Keefe was ""discovered"" hitting balls on the range at Deer Track Golf Resort by Billy Delk, who was the head professional at the two courses.
""I was hitting some balls and Billy happened to be watching,"" remembered O'Keefe. ""When I was finished, he asked what school I played for and I told him I was out of school.""
""He asked me how long I’d been playing and I told him about 6 months. He said, 'We need to talk. Do you have any ambitions of playing golf?'""
O'Keefe wrote Delk a letter asking for an assistant's job. Delk didn’t have an opening, but he did offer her help with her game.
When school ended in June, O'Keefe didn't need much convincing to come to Surfside Beach to work with the veteran teacher.
Though Delk had seen her hitting balls just one time at the practice range, the former Clemson player knew she had the potential to be and outstanding golfer.

The athletic ability and competitiveness that made her an All American catcher were apparent even on the practice tee. She also has the desire needed to make it. At Deer Track, she practices 8 to 10 hours a day.
""She had some basic swings that were good,"" said Delk. ""She had a natural athletic ability. It is just something you spot in an athlete.""
Though Delk now teaches at Indigo Creek, Deer Track owner Gary Schaal and his staff have helped O'Keefe with support and advice when she isn't with Delk.

""I've always believed that the only thing that will stop me is not being able to generate enough funds,"" said O'Keefe while taking a break in the Deer Track snack bar. ""This is like a gold mine. ""Billy, Gary and the assistants have been just great to me. They always help me when I need it.""
The 5-foot-5 125-pound O'Keefe plays from the regular men's tees. She drives the ball 235 and has superior touch around the greens.

She's taken these talents with work and dedication to improve her game to the next level. Though she never played golf seriously before coming to Deer Track, the former University of San Diego catcher firmly believed she could excel in the sport if given the opportunity.
""When I was in college, I was on crutches watching golf on TV,"" remembered O'Keefe. ""I said to myself, that doesn't look so hard.""
Finding a place to play has always been O'Keefe's major problem. Growing up in Westchester County suburbs of New York City, O'Keefe lived near several prominent country clubs, but no public courses.
Without a country club membership, playing golf was difficult. But not impossible for O'Keefe. ""I spent my life sneaking on,"" she said with a smile. ""You just gotta do what you gotta do.""

My brothers and I use to just walk in to the pool a Westchester Country Club with towels and wave at the members, and they figured we were members. One time my brothers got in trouble and were suspended from a club and they weren't even members.""
O'Keefe had the same problem after college. Even when she applied to courses outside of New York, she couldn't find a place to play.
That all changed when she moved into a condo near the clubhouse at Deer Track and began taking lessons from Delk. About six months ago, she bought a membership at Deer Track.
O'Keefe has had money problems since she got here. Her family helps out, but she has to scrimp and save just to survive.
Last summer, O'Keefe worked nights as a waitress, I use to only eat when I was at work,"" said O'Keefe. ""I got real sick when I was doing that.""
O'Keefe said she isn't getting impatient with her rugged lifestyle. She's convinced she'll eventually be rewarded for her hard work.
When will she be ready to take on the LPGA Tour? ""That's such a hard question,"" admitted O'Keefe. ""Who knows? I just really don’t worry about that - I just worry about getting better.""
This year, O'Keefe has shown promise. Besides winning four tournaments in South Carolina, she's been competitive in two national events.
Delk predicts she'll be ready for the Futures Tour, the ladies' version of the Hogan Tour, next Spring.

""She's getting very, very close to getting to that level of play,"" said Delk. ""The biggest thing that's going to hold her back is monetary. She can go as far as she wants if she can achieve the monetary backing to go through that next level and make the next step to the professional level.""
If she gets there, O'Keefe won’t be driving a $1 car.
